title: Expression language
content:
The Expression Language is a language that enables you to construct expressions that you can enter in different parts of the Integration Studio user interface.

Tip: You can use the Expression execution details field in the integration execution history details page (accessed from the Endpoint page) to view the actual expression evaluation result.

The expressions can be of the following types:

  • A logical expression (&&, ||, ==, !=)
  • A mathematical expression (+, -, /, *)
  • A conditional expression (if-else)
  • An object property (Objects)
  • A function call (DSL functions)

You can define complex expressions by combining these types of expressions. Every value which is not a Boolean, number or string is an expression.

Note The Integration Studio configuration UI supports the Unicode character set.

Supported data types

The expressions return a value of a specific data type. The following data types are supported.

Data type Example

Boolean

true, false

String

'hello': Returns hello

'he\'l\'lo': Returns he'l'lo

Double

0.5

Integer

4

Object

Key a: Hello

Key b: World

Array

['cat', 'dog', 'cow']
Note: When constructing an expression, make sure that the data type of the return value for the expression matches the required data type for the context in which you are working.
Note: The Integration Studio doesn't support arrays with empty elements (example: [element1,,element3]). Note that these are different from arrays with an empty value (example: [element1,'',element3]) or null value (example: [element1,null,element3]), which are supported.

Conditional expressions

Syntax: if (condition) {expression 1} else {expression 2}

Returns expression 1 if the condition is true; otherwise, returns expression 2.

Note You can use conditional expressions on their own—you can't add them in other constructs, such as DSL functions or arrays.

Examples

Object property reference

<object>.<key>

Returns the value of the specified object property. For example, Data.Subject = 'My change request'.

Equality operator

<object>?.<key> == 'user1'

Returns true if the value of the specified key is user1; otherwise returns false.

Using + to concatenate strings 

<object>.<key1 of type string> + <object>.<key2 of type string>

Returns a concatenated string of values of the specified keys.

Using + as the mathematical operator

<object>.<key1 of type number> + <object>.<key2 of type number>

Returns the result of the calculation.

DSL function concat

concat(<object>.<key1 of type string>, <object>.<key2 of type string>)

Returns a concatenated string of values of the specified keys.

DSL function substring

substring(<object>.<key1>, length(<object>.<key1>)-3)

Returns the last 3 characters of the value of the specified key.

Conditional expression

if (<object>?.<key> == 'user1') {'Yes'} else {'No'}

Returns "Yes" if the value of the specified key is user1; otherwise returns "No".

Conditional expression (evaluating the validity of the object property)

if (<object>?.<key> != undefined) {'Yes'} else {'No'}

Returns "Yes" if the value of the specified key is a valid value; otherwise returns "No".
